availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

Respectfully

Morgan County
July 2nd, 1860
To his excellency
Gov Magoffin,

Your petitioners would most sincerely and earnestly ask your exceelency to grant a pardon to William R Watson, who has during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court been convicted of manslaughter The immediate and sole cause of the difficulty which led to the death of Dillion Phipps or Rose, was the fact that in the absence of Watson from home the said Phips entered his house at midnights and attempted by force to carnally know Mrs Watson and in the heat of that passion which overcomes every honorable man when the honor of his wife is thus insulted, he slew Phips & altho. not justified by the law, we think he ought not to be punished and appeal to your Excellency to pardon him

Respectfully,
W. R. Whitt
Jas. N. Lykins
D. C. Lykins

Morgan County
July 2nd 1860
To his Excellency
Gov. Magoffin

Your petitioners would sincerely and earnestly ask your excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson who has been convicted of manslaughter during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court, The immediate and sole cause of the difficulty which led to the death of Dillard Phipps or Rose was the fact that in the absence of Mr Watson from home the said Phipps entered his house at midnight and attempted by force to carnally know Mrs Watson and in the heat of that passion which over-comes every honorably man, When the honor of his wife is thus insulted he slew Phipps and although not justified by the law we think he aught not to be punished and appeal to your excellency to pardon him

Respectfully
Alfred Davis

Morgan County
July 2 1860
To his excellency
Gov Megoffin

Your petitioners would most earnestly and respectfully ask your excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson who has been convicted during the present term of this Court of the offense of manslaughter. The immediate and sole cause which led to the difficulty that resulted in the death of Dillard Phipps was the fact that in Watsons absence from home Phipps at the hour of midnight entered his house and attempted cernally to know Mrs. Watson, -- Mr Watson was driven by that impulse of passion which drives on every honorable man, under like circumstances, and though he committed a violent act he did it in vindication of the insulted honor of his wife And we do hope your excellency will interpose and pardon him

Respectfully
William K McNeill
Joseph Ellim

Morgan County
July 2nd 1860
To his Excellency
Gov. Mcgoffin

The undersigned women of morgan Country would earnestly appeal to your Excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson, who has been convicted of the offense of manslaughter during the present term of the Mason Morgan Circuit Court. The immediate and only cause of the dificulty -- which resulted in the death of Phips or Rose was the fact that at the hour of midnight in the absence of Mr Watson, Mr Phips entered his house and attempted by force to polute the virture of Mrs Watson, Luce and as all honorable are, Mr Watson committed the deed in vindication of the insulted honor of his wife, understanding that your excellency is both fath husband & father, we can appeal to you with the m confidence that you will appreciate the high indignity which was offered to Mr Watson, and that therefore you will let no honorable man be punished who will thus do an act even of violence if when one who attempts to destroy the peace of the Domestic Circle by insult upon the unsullied honor of a virtuous wife
Respectfully

Virginia Carter
Elizabeth Carter
Mariah Carter
Margaret Pieratt
Rosina Peck
Nancy Peck
Seusin Peck

Elizabeth J Stamper
Mary ann Gevedon

July 2nd 1860
To his Excellency
Gov Mcgoffin

The undersigned women of Morgan County would earnestly appeal to your excellency to grant a pardon to Wm R Watson. Who has been convicted of the offence of manslaughter during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court. The immediate and only cause of the difficulty which resulted in the death of Dillard Rose on Phipps was the fact at the hour of midnight, in the absence of Mr Watson Mr Phipps entered his house and attempted by force to polute the virture of Mrs Watson, led on as all honorable men are, Mr Watson committed the deed in vindication of the insulted of his wife. Understanding that your Excellency is both husband and father, we can appeal to your with the confidence that you will appreciate the high indignity which was offered to Watson and that therefore you will let know no honorable man be punished who will thus do an act even of violation if done upon one who attempts to destroy the peace of the domestic circle by a ruthless insult upon the unsullied honor of a virtuous wife,

Respectfully
Margaret Stamper

Morgan County
July 2nd 1860
To his Excellency
Gov. Mcgoffin

The undersigned women of Morgan County would earnestly appeal to your excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson who has been convicted of the offense of manslaughter during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court, The immediate and only cause of the difficulty which resulted in the death of Dillard Phipps or Rose, was the fact that at the hour of midnight in the absence of Mr. Watson, Mr Phips entered his house and attempted by force to polute the virtue of Mrs Watson, led on as all honorable men are, Mr Watson committed the deed, in vindication of the insulted honor of his wife, understanding that your excellency is both husband and father we ever appeal to you with the mere confidence, that you will appreciate the high indignity which was offered to Watson and that therefore you will let no honorable man be punished who will thus do an acte even of violence if done upon one who attempts to destroy the the peace of the domestic Circle by a ruthless insult upon the unsullied honor of a virtious wife

Respectfully
Ludemy Barker

Morgan County
July 2nd 1860
To his excellency,
Go Megoffin

The undersigned women of Morgan County would earnestly appeal to your excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson; who has been convicted of the offinse of Manslaughter during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court. The immediate and only cause of the difficulty which resulted in the death of Dillard Rose or Phips was the fact that at the hour of midnight in the absence of Mr Watson Mr Phips entered his house and attempted by force to pollute the virture of Mrs Watson Led on as all honorable men are. Mr Watson committed the deed in vindication of the insulted honor of his wife. Understanding that your excellency is both husband and father, and can appeal to you with the mere confidence that you will appreciate the high indignity which was offered to Watson, and that therefore you will let no honorable man be punished who will thus do an act even of violence, if done upon one who attempts to destroy the peace of the domestic Circle by a ruthless insult upon the unsullied honor of a virtuous wife

Respectfully,
Martha Steele

Margan County
July 2nd 1860
To his Excellency
Gov Mcgoffin

The undersigned women of Morgan County would earnestly appeal to your Excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson, who has been Convicted of the offense of manslaughter during the current term of the Morgan Circuit Court, The immediate and only cause of the diffilculty which resulted in the dealth of Dillard Phips or Rose was the fact that at the hour of midnight in the absence of Mr Watson Mr Phips entered the his house and attempted by force to polute the virtue of Mrs watson led on as all honorable men are Mr Watson Committed the deed in vindication of the insulted honor of his wife understanding that your Excellency is both husband and father, we can appeal to you with much confidence that you will appreciate the high indignity which was offered to Watson and that therefore you will let no honorable man be punished who will thus do an act even of violence if done upon one who attepts to destroy the power of the domestic circle by a ruthless insult upon the unsullied honor of a virtuous wife,

Respectfully

Hazle Green Ky 12 Oct 1861
Mr J, W, South
Dear sir

I send you a Petition from the Citizens of Morgan County for W R Watson who is a Convict in the State Pentintiary which would have been Presented to the Gov -- this had Wm Lykins here willing to have gave up the Papers he held on to them trying to get Watson's friends to make up money for him to go to Frankfort till yesterday Billy Watson's wife got them & brought them to me.
I therefore send them to you hoping you will present them to the govenor

Respy yours
W. H. Tauller

ertson

Morgan County
July 2nd 1860
To his Excellency
Gov Mcgoffin

Your petitioners would most sincerely and earnestly ask you excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson who has during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court, been convicted of the offence of manslaughter. The immediate and sole cause of the difficulty which resulted in the death of Dillard Phipps or Rose was the fact that in the absense of Watson from home the said Phipps entered his house at midnight and attempted by force to carnally know Mrs Watson, and in the heat of that passion which overcomes every honorable man, when the honor of his wife is thus insulted he slew Phipps and although not justified by the law we think he ought not to be punished and appeal to your excellency to pardon him

Respectfully
Harvy M Barker
Morgan Barker
Peter J Hutchinson

Henry M Hutchinson

No 2
Morgan County
July 2nd 1860
To his excellency
Gov Mcgoffin

Your petitioners would most sincerly and earnestly ask your excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson who has, during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court, been convicted of the offence of manslaughter The immediate and sole cause of this difficulty which led to the death of Dillard Phips or Rose, was the fact that in the absence of Mr Watson from home the said Phips entered his house at the hour of midnight, and attempted by force to carnally know Mrs Watson and in the heat of that passion which over comes every honorable man when the honor of his wife is thus insulted he slew Phips and although not justified by ^the^ law we think he ought not to be punished, and appeal to your excellency to pardon him

Respectfully
George W Nickel
Caleb May
Z W Brown
George H Stamper
Wm Ross
Travis Lawson
James H Robinson
Wm T Lawson
H. J. Spradling
Hugh
E D Lawson
I James F Crain
Joseph H Gelvin
O. P. Sorrell
Robert Eaton

Morgan County
July 2nd, 1860
To his Excellency
Gov. Mcgoffin

The undersigned women of Morgan County would earnestly appeal to your excellency to grant a pardon to William R Watson who has been convicted of the offence of manslaughter during the present term of the Morgan Circuit Court,

The immediate and only Cause of the dificulty which resulted in the death of Dillard Rose or Phips was the fact that at the hour of midnight in the absence of Mr Watson, Mr Phips entered his house and attempted by force to polute the virture of Mrs Watson, Led on as all honorable men are, Mr Watson committed the deed in vindication of the insulted honor of his wife, Understanding that you are both husband and father, we can appeal to your with the mere Confidence that you will appreciate the high indignity which was offered to Mr Watson and that therefore you will let no honorable man be punished, who will thus do an act even of violence, if done upon one who attempts to destroy the peace of the Domestic Circle by a ruthless insult upon the insullied honor of a virtuous wife

Respectfuly
Mrs. Silvey Ferguson
Mrs Viney Hany

Morgan County
July 2 1860
To. his Excelency

your petitioners would most respectfully and earnestly ask your excelency to grant a pardon to William R Watson -- who has been convicted during the present term of the court of the offence of Manslaughter the Immediate and sole Cause of which led to the difficulty that resulted in the Death of Dillard phipps was in fact that in Watson's absence from home phipps at the hour of Midnight entered his house and attempted for forcibly to have Carnal Intercars with Mrs Watson Mr Watson was driven by that Impulse of honor which prompts evry honorable man under like Circumstances, and thogh he commited an Rash act done it in vendication of the Insulted honor of his wife and we hope your excelincy will Interfere and pardon him

Respectfully
Miles Terry
Wm Lumpkins
Richard S. E.s.q.
